message.content:
cs.IT, cs.SI, cs.DS, cs.ITP, cs.LG. 

The paper deals with polar transforms, which are a central operation in the study of polar codes, and focuses on non-stationary memoryless sources on possibly infinite source alphabets. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the Information Theory (cs.IT) sub-category. Additionally, the paper deals with erasure distributions and recursive formulas, which are common topics in the Signal Processing (cs.SI) and Data Structures and Algorithms (cs.DS) sub-categories. The paper also mentions elementary techniques in lattice theory, which suggests that it may belong to the Information Theory and Probability (cs.ITP) sub-category. Finally, the paper deals with multilevel source polarization, which is a topic that falls under the Machine Learning (cs.LG) sub-category.
